thread.title: Baseball’s rule, not Chase Utley, is at fault
thread.title_full: Baseball’s rule, not Chase Utley, is at fault - The Washington Post

author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Baseball’s rule, not Chase Utley, is at fault
text:
New York Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada falls after a slide by Los Angeles Dodgers' Chase Utley on Oct. 10. (John Mccoy/Los Angeles Daily News/Associated Press) October 18 at 7:46 PM Regarding Thomas Boswell’s Oct. 13 Sports column, “ MLB should dive into removing the takeout slide ”:
Why is second base the only one of the four at which a runner is allowed (even encouraged) to interfere with a fielder’s throw to another base? It makes sense to allow a slider the same latitude as a base runner who is attempting to avoid a tag in a rundown.
Los Angeles Dodgers second baseman Chase Utley should not be vilified for sliding similarly to hundreds of other base runners over the years. But Mets infielder Rubén Tejada would seem to have grounds for a lawsuit against Major League Baseball for allowing runners to “take out” fielders outside the baseline.
Bill Smith , Bluffton, S.C.
